title: Undercover Economist Interview Series - Philip Tetlock
desc: The importance of accurate forecasting cannot be underestimated. It can spell the difference between prosperity and penury, progress and collapse, even peace and war. When it comes to making predictions about the future, the average expert is about as accurate as a dart-throwing chimpanzee ? as Tetlock concluded in his 2005 bestseller   after analysing 27,450 forecasts made by hundreds of experts who make a career out of forecasting political or economic events. He discovered that the more ?pre-eminent? the experts were, the less accurate their predictions tended to be. ? In his new book  , Tetlock and co-author Dan Gardner show that our desire for meaningful predictions about the future is far from futile, however. Learn more about their approach they term as the ?fox? style of thinking, which are a few simple training exercises that can improve the average person?s ability to predict the future by a staggering 20 per cent. ? Don?t miss what promises to be a fascinating evening of discussion and a unique opportunity to learn ways in which we are able to improve our foresight and make more accurate descriptions. ?  is Leonore Anneberg University Professor of Psychology at the University of Pennsylvania.
